choices.text: Trisomy 8 is present in superficial fibromatosis

questions.text: Which of the following is FALSE regarding fibromatosis?
questions.solution:
Fibromatosis

  • Benign (never metastasize), but infiltrative with strong tendency to recur. (Choice D)
  • 2 Major Divisions:
    • Superficial: E.g., Palmar, plantar, penile. Small. Slowly-growing. Usually Older.
    • Deep ("Desmoid-type"):g., Abdominal, mesenteric. More Aggressive. High-recurrence rate (>50%). Involve deep structures. Usu. Younger. Interestingly, microscopic margins do NOT predict Recurrence.
  • Microscopy :-
    • Infiltrative growth into surrounding structures (esp. Skeletal muscle).
    • Broad, sweeping fascicles.
    • Uniform spindled cells with small, pale nuclei with pinpoint nucleoli.
    • Moderate amounts of collagen, surrounding cells, in slightly myxoid Background.
    • With age, less cellular and more collagen.
    • Microhaemorrhages and scattered chronic inflammation.
  • IHC: Nuclear β-catenin (choice B) (more cells with deep than superficial). Some actin (+), desmin. (Choice A)
  • Molecular: Deep fibromatosis is associated with FAP and mutations in The APC/β-catenin (CTNNB1) pathway.
  • Deep fibromatosis has 2 characteristic molecular alterations, including trisomy 8 in up to 25% of cases and deletion of Sq in 10% of cases (choice D).

Key Takeaways:

  • Fibromatosis: Benign but infiltrative; deep type recurs >50%.
  • IHC: Positive for β-catenin and desmin.
  • Trisomy 8: Found in deep fibromatosis.
  • Microscopy: Spindle cells, collagen, chronic inflammation.

questions.text: The postulated cell of origin of this tongue lesion is:
questions.solution:
Granular cell tumor -

  • Benign neoplasm with neuroectodermal differentiation.
  • Epithelioid to spindled cells with abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm highlighted by PAS+ve.
  • Full of lysosomes due to inactivating mutations in ATP6AP1 or 2 → Granular appearance
  • Stains :- (+) s100, CD68, Inhibin, Calretinin
  • Congenital (gingival) granular cell tumor (Congenital Epulis) : although looks similar, s-100(-), located on gingiva at birth.
  • Schwannian differentiation

Key Takeaways:

  • Granular Cell Tumor: Benign with Schwannian origin.
  • Histology: Epithelioid/spindle cells, granular cytoplasm (PAS+).
  • IHC: Positive for S100, CD68, Inhibin, Calretinin.
  • Congenital Type: S100-negative, located on gingiva at birth.

questions.text: The translocation t(2;13)(q35;ql4) is associated with which of the following variants of rhabdomyosarcoma (depicted in this image)?
questions.solution:
75-80% of alveolar variant of rhabdomyosarcoma contain the translocation t(2; 13 )( q35;q 14) ( choice C ).

  • The embryonal and pleomorphic types of rhabdomyosarcoma do not exhibit recurrent molecular alterations (choices A, B, D)

ALVEOLAR RHABDOMYOSARCORNA:-

  • More aggressive than embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma
  • Often seen in adolescents and young adults. Present in deep soft tissue of extremities and sinuses.
  • Morphology :-
    • Highly cellular "small round blue cell" tumor
    • Monomorphous round nuclei
    • Often nest-like arrangement (alveolar appearance)
    • Absence of strap cells, tadpole cells, etc.
  • Molecular :- FOXO1 fusions with either PAX3 or PAX7
  • IHC :- Strong, diffuse myogenin suggests this diagnosis. Patchy neuroendocrine staining.

Key Takeaways:

  • Alveolar Rhabdomyosarcoma: Associated with t(2;13)(q35;q14) translocation (FOXO1-PAX3/7 fusion).
  • Aggressive: Affects adolescents/young adults; often in extremities or sinuses.
  • Histology: Small round blue cells, nest-like (alveolar) arrangement, lacks strap/tadpole cells.
  • IHC: Strong, diffuse myogenin positivity.

questions.text: The most common location of extraskeletal Ewing sarcoma is:
questions.solution:
Ewing's Sarcoma

  • Malignant.
  • Most common in the diaphysis of long bones (but can be in any Bone and soft tissue).
  • On imaging causes a mulitlaminated periosteal reaction→"onion skinning"
  • Most common in children and young adults
  • Small round blue cell morphology. Uniform. Stippled chromatin and scant clear to eosinophilic cytoplasm. Can form rosettes
  • IHC: CD99 diffuse strong membranous staining (not specific though) NKX2-2 (much more specific). FLI1 and ERG in cases with corresponding Fusions. Occasional keratin expression.
  • Molecular: EWSR1 fusions, most commonly with FL1, sometimes with ERG, Or rarely other combinations.
  • The most common location of extraskeletal Ewing sarcoma is the chest wall/paravertebral region (choice D). The head and neck area and the gonads are not common locations for this lesion (choices A, B, C).

Key Takeaways:

  • Ewing sarcoma: Malignant, common in long bones.
  • Imaging: "Onion skinning".
  • Histology: Small blue cells, rosettes.
  • IHC: CD99, NKX2-2.
  • Location: Chest wall most common for extraskeletal Ewing sarcoma.

choices.text: Half of cases occur in patients with neurofibromatosis
It typically presents as a painful, rapidly enlarging mass.
Most lesions arise from major nerve trunks such as the brachial plexus
On gross examination, the lesion exhibits diffusely infiltrative growth.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumor (MPNST)

  • Malignant
  • Adults
  • Frequently in setting of NF1. (Choice A)
  • Often poor prognosis
  • painful, rapidly enlarging mass in the trunk, extremities, or head and neck, (choices B)
  • The majority of cases arise from major nerve trunks, such as the brachial And sacral plexi (choice C).
  • While the lesion is clearly infiltrative by microscopic examination, the gross appearance may be deceptively circumscribed (choice D).
  • Must arise from a peripheral nerve or pre-existing peripheral nerve sheath tumor or display histologic/IHC evidence of nerve sheath differentiation.
  • Variable appearance, can resemble undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma or fibrosarcoma.
  • Spindled cells arranged in sweeping fascicles.
  • Densely cellular areas alternate with less cellular areas giving a "marble-like" effect.
  • Can have herringbone architecture.
  • Wavy, buckled nuclei.
  • Geographic necrosis and/or mitotic activity (often greater than 10/10 HPFs)
  • IHC: Patchy S100 and SOX10.
  • Loss of H3K27me3 expression (associated with worse prognosis. Not entirely specific-see with SUZ12 and EED gene inactivation)
  • Subtypes:
    MPNST with rhabdomyoblastic differentiation ("Malignant triton tumor")
    MPNST with glandular differentiation
    Epithelioid MPNST-composed of polygonal, epithelioid cells. Unique strong, diffuse S100 staining.

Key Takeaways:

  • MPNST: Malignant, common in NF1.
  • Presentation: Painful, rapidly enlarging mass.
  • Origin: Arises from major nerve trunks.
  • Histology: Spindle cells, "marble-like" effect.
  • IHC: S100, SOX10, H3K27me3 loss.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the following peripheral nerve sheath tumor?
questions.solution:
Neurofibroma

  • Most commonly solitary and sporadic.
  • Multiple NF is a hallmark of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), also Known as von Recklinghausen disease. Higher, but still low, risk of transformation.
  • Can be cutaneous (most common), intraneural, or diffuse.
  • Plexiform NF→ almost exclusively in NF1; higher risk of MPNST.
  • Mixture of Schwann cells, perineurial-like cells, fibroblastic cells, And entrapped axons.
  • Randomly oriented spindled cells with wavy, hyperchromatic nuclei. Often hypocellular and variably myxoid Thin and thick collagen strands ("shredded carrot collagen") (shown in the image)
  • Entrapped axons are overrun by lesion and scattered throughout.
  • IHC: Diffuse S100 (+) (but less so than schwannoma). Moderate CD34.
  • Neurofilament shows entrapped axons within lesion.
  • Types: Can be pigmented or show ancient change.

Key Takeaways:

  • Neurofibroma: Benign, associated with NF1.
  • Histology: Randomly oriented spindle cells, wavy nuclei, "shredded carrot collagen".
  • IHC: Diffuse S100, CD34 (+), neurofilament shows entrapped axons.
  • Types: Cutaneous, intraneural, diffuse, plexiform (high MPNST risk).

questions.text: Which of the following variants of neurofibroma are almost entirely associated with neurofibromatosis?
questions.solution:
NEUROFIBROMATOSIS :-

  • Multiple neurofibromas represent the most important component of the genetically determined disorder known as type 1 neurofibromatosis or von Recklinghausen disease
  • autosomal dominant disease
  • The responsible gene (NF1) is located on chromosome 17q11.2 and encodes a ubiquitous protein known as neurofibromin, which is necessary for the correct negative regulation of RAS proteins
  • Site: axilla, thigh, buttock, deep soft tissue, orbit, mediastinum, retroperitoneum, tongue, gastrointestinal tract, and many others.
  • Plexiform neurofibromas may result in massive enlargement of a limb or some other part of the body ("elephantiasis neuromatosa").
  • In addition to neurofibromas, patients often have café au lait spots
  • microscopically of an increase in the amount of melanin in the epidermal basal layer and is sometimes seen overlying a neurofibroma.

Key Takeaways:

  • Plexiform neurofibroma: Exclusively associated with NF1.
  • NF1: Autosomal dominant, gene on chromosome 17q11.2, regulates RAS proteins.
  • Features: Multiple neurofibromas, café au lait spots, potential "elephantiasis neuromatosa".
  • Sites: Axilla, mediastinum, retroperitoneum, orbit, tongue, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria present in isolation is sufficient for the diagnosis of neurofibromatosis, type II?
questions.solution:
Type 2 neurofibromatosis is genetically distinct from type 1, resulting from an alteration of the NF2 gene located on chromosome 22q12 encoding merlin.

  • It is characterized by the presence of a Variety of neoplasms in the CNS, the most distinctive of which are bilateral acoustic schwannomas. - a single criterion for NF2 (Choice A)
  • Meningiomas, astrocytomas, and tumors of other types also occur.
  • The other choices presented must be accompanied by at least 1 other finding as well as a unilateral acoustic schwannoma (choices B, C, D).

Key Takeaways:

  • NF2: Caused by NF2 gene mutation on chromosome 22q12.
  • Single diagnostic criterion: Bilateral acoustic schwannomas.
  • Other findings (e.g., meningiomas, unilateral schwannomas) require additional criteria.

questions.text: The most common location of the lesion depicted in these histopathology (image A) and immunohistochemistry (smooth muscle actin- SMA) (image B) pictures is:
questions.solution:
Glomus tumor

  • Benign.
  • Tumor derived from glomus body (specialized AV anastomosis that regulates heat)
  • Often red-blue nodules in the deep dermis of extremities
  • Fingers/toes.
  • Often painful
  • Microscopy :- very richly vascular network separating tumor cell nests. Distinctive cells with round nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  • IHC :- smooth muscle actin (SMA +)

Key Takeaways:

  • Glomus tumor: Benign, painful, red-blue nodule.
  • Location: Most common in fingers/toes.
  • Histology: Vascular network, round nuclei, eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  • IHC: SMA (+).

questions.text: Which of the following special stain may be particularly helpful in the diagnosis of this malignant soft tissue lesion from the thigh mass of a young adult?
questions.solution:
Alveolar soft part sarcoma

  • Malignant
  • Often young adults
  • Microscopy :- organoid nests of large, uniform, epithelioid cells with abundant, eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm.
    Round nuclei with prominent nucleoli
  • PAS demonstrates rhabdoid or rod shaped intracytoplasmic inclusions.
  • IHC :- TFE3 (+), S100 and desmin (-/+)
  • Molecular: ASPSCR1-TFE3 fusion
  • The neoplastic population in alveolar soft part sarcoma notably contains PAS-positive, diastase-resistant rhomboid or rod-shaped crystals in 80% of cases.
  • While these can also be seen on an H&E stain, they are particularly pronounced on the PAS stain (choice A).
  • PAS without diastase also confirms the presence of glycogen in these cells, but is less specific (choice B).
  • Colloidal iron & Warthin-Starry stains are not helpful in alveolar soft part sarcoma (choices C, D)

Key Takeaways:

  • Alveolar soft part sarcoma: Malignant, young adults, thigh mass.
  • Histology: Organ-like nests, granular cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli.
  • PAS with diastase: Highlights diastase-resistant crystals (80% cases).
  • IHC: TFE3 (+); molecular: ASPSCR1-TFE3 fusion.
  • Other stains (colloidal iron, Warthin-Starry) are not useful
